title: AV-Surf: Surface-Enhanced Geometry-Aware Novel-View Acoustic Synthesis
author: Hadam Baek (Korea University), Hannie Shin (Korea University), Jiyoung Seo (Korea University), Chanwoo Kim (Korea University), Saerom Kim (Korea University), Hyeongbok Kim (Testworks), Sangpil Kim (Korea University), ...
relevance_why: This paper presents a novel approach to acoustic synthesis that integrates surface normals and geometric details, which could significantly advance Haohe Liu's work on audio generation and quality enhancement.
background: This research focuses on generating spatially accurate binaural audio by synthesizing realistic sound propagation in complex real-world environments from a novel viewpoint.
contribution: AV-Surf introduces a geometry-aware approach that utilizes surface-enhanced features to accurately model sound propagation in real-world scenarios, achieving improved binaural audio synthesis.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often relied on limited geometric or visual cues, leading to inaccuracies in auditory experiences.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves acoustic modeling by integrating surface normals and 3D geometry, refining audio synthesis to achieve more realistic sound propagation.

key_innovation: Combines geometric and surface information with neural architectures to enhance audio synthesis, bridging visual and auditory models effectively.
real_world_impact: The method has practical applications in virtual and augmented reality, gaming, and other industries requiring immersive audio experiences.
limitations: The model's performance is directly dependent on the quality of the geometric priors and may require high computational resources for real-time implementation.

new_terms.surface normals: **Surface normals** are vectors that are perpendicular to the surface at a given point, crucial for understanding how surfaces interact with sound waves.
new_terms.geometry-aware: **Geometry-aware** approaches consider the shapes and structures of environments to improve how technologies perceive and interact with spatial audio.
